greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n such that the largest part is twice the smallest part.
comment: Also number of partitions of n such that if the largest part occurs k times, then the number of parts is 2k. Example: a(8)=4 because we have [7,1], [6,2], [5,3] and [3,3,1,1].
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
maple: b:= proc(n, i, t) option remember: `if`(n=0, 1, `if`(i<t, 0,
mathematica: Table[Count[IntegerPartitions[n], p_ /; 2 Min[p] = = Max[p]], {n, 40}] (* _Clark Kimberling_, Feb 16 2014 *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 12 2006
